intro: Ipomoea marmorata subsp. somalica, commonly known as the Somalian morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the Horn of Africa. It belongs to the Convolvulaceae family and is characterized by its striking, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink and violet. The plant produces heart-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture, and its vines can climb or trail along the ground. It thrives in warm, sunny climates and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. The subspecies is distinguished by its unique floral patterns and is of interest to botanists and horticulturists alike.
